article: " You probably don't remember me," she said. Then she pulled out a piece of paper from her _ and gave it to me. It was my handwriting. As the assistant of the Honors Programs at the university, one of my _ was to review student transcripts to make sure they could _ in Honors. It was common for students to have a(n) _ start and they could no longer continue in Honors after their first term. However, sometimes their _ term report cards would still be sent to us even though the students were no longer in the program. The note she handed me _ , " Congratulations on your excellent second term. You may have been _ with your grades, but you should feel _ of how you've made some progress. Best of luck in keeping up the good work, and you'll be able to succeed." The student went on and said, " You can't know what this _ to me. I've carried it in my purse for three years and pulled it out anytime I didn't want to do my _ . For three years I've been _ to enter your office and giving you this note and this _ . " she handed me her latest transcript with good marks. We were both _ . She cried and I _ to. Writing the note seemed like nothing to me, but it meant so _ to her. I really had no idea that my actions had such meaning.
